docs.lead_paragraph: Nathan Rowman was in his late 80's when he was hospitalized for a suspected heart problem. Seemingly overnight, Mr. Rowman, who had been running his own business and going to work every day, became so confused that his children considered putting him in a nursing home. But before that happened, the family consulted a geriatric specialist who suspected that the medication given to him in the hospital, and not any organic brain deterioration, might be causing his confusion. When the drug was discontinued, Mr. Rowman became his old self again, and after being discharged from the hospital, he returned to work. Is Something Really Wrong? Many things occur as people age. As Dr. Elaine J. Amella noted in a recent issue of The American Journal of Nursing, ''Heart muscles thicken, arteries stiffen, lung tissues diminish, brain and spinal cord degenerate, kidneys shrink, and bladder muscles weaken.''

headline.main: Aging and Infirmity: Twinned No Longer

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column describes symptoms of illness or other medical problems in elderly people that are often misdiagnosed or attributed to aging; Dr Elaine J Amella, Medical University of South Carolina College of Nursing associate dean of research, provides possible explanations for symptoms; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Do not assume that a symptom is a normal sign of aging. Get it checked out without delay.

docs.lead_paragraph: The genes that specify the architecture of the human brain seem to have started evolving faster some 20 million years ago, when the great apes split off from Old World monkeys. The genes then doubled their speed of evolution after the human lineage parted ways with that of chimpanzees five million years ago. This is the inference drawn by Dr. Bruce T. Lahn and colleagues at the University of Chicago after comparing the DNA sequence of brain genes in several species of primate. Their report is published in last month's issue of Cell.

headline.main: Human Brain Design Gets a New Timetable

docs.abstract: University of Chicago researcher Dr Bruce T Lahn and colleagues conduct study comparing DNA sequence of brain genes in several different primate species; findings, published in journal Cell, suggest that around 20 million years ago human brain genes began evolving more quickly than other primates; researchers have established macaque, Old World monkey, as baseline to examine and compare human and chimp genes; findings differ from earlier studies that suggest only few genes would need to change for chimp brains to function like human brain (M)
docs.snippet: Scientists comparing the DNA sequence of brain genes in several species of primate have found that the genes that specify the architecture of the human brain seem to have started evolving faster some 20 million years ago.
